<strong>Previewing</strong> means looking at what you are reading for just a few minutes and hunting for clues that will help you understand what you are about to read.<strong>&nbsp; </strong><br /><br />You can preview<strong> </strong>any material that you are reading, including books, chapters, articles, and even short pieces of writing such as poems.<br /><br />When you preview, you should think like a writer.&nbsp; How has the writer organized his or her writing?&nbsp; What clues has the writer&nbsp; given you that will help you understand his or her ideas?<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">Previewing</span><br /><br />Scan what you are reading</p><p>Think like a writer</p><p>Hunt for clues to help you understand the author&#39;s idea</p>","headerText":"Previewing the text"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"8"},"leftText":"<p>To preview the Op-Ed, read it quickly or scan it and look for these elements: &nbsp;</p><ul style=\"padding-left: 15px;\"><li>&nbsp;title</li><li>&nbsp;author</li><li>date of publication</li><li>bold headings or subtitles</li><li>visuals or graphics that may be part of the article<br />&nbsp;</li></ul>","rightText":"<table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"width: 100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p><span class=\"ju-normal\" style=\"color:black;font-family:lato,sans-serif;font-size:16px;\"><strong>Town Music Shop Blows the Horn on Needed Music Education</strong><br />by Henry Schwinkle<br />henschwink@milltown.com</span></p><p><img alt=\"toolbar of social media icons\" src=\"data:image/png;base64,\" /></p><p>(March 3, 2016) The recent unfortunate incident in our town has created speculation about ways to keep our children out of trouble. . .</p><p><a href=\"S3_BUCKET_/CS6/Op-Ed.html\" onclick=\"window.open(this.href, '', 'resizable=no,status=no,location=no,toolbar=no,menubar=no,fullscreen=no,scrollbars=no,dependent=no,width=800,left=100,height=600,top=50'); <span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">These are not presented as separate headings, but they are the first sentences of each paragraph. &nbsp; </span>The bold headings help you <strong>anticipate, </strong>or guess, what the text will be about. &nbsp;<br /><br />The first two bold headings <span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">are The day the music died, we have lost something, and Time on learning, deciding what&#39;s important.&nbsp; They </span>make a statement about the problem, which is the lack of music instruction in the schools.<br /><br />The rest of the headings state why music education is important. <span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">For example, one of them is Participation in an instrumental music program keeps kids busy and committed. </span><br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"width: 100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p><strong>. . .<span class=\"marker\">The day the music died&mdash;we have lost something</span>.&nbsp; </strong>It is not difficult to establish a connection between this incident and the loss of music programs in our schools. . .</p><p><strong>. . .<span class=\"marker\">Time on learning&mdash;deciding what&rsquo;s important</span></strong>.&nbsp; All these programs have been cut or reduced due to policies that demand more time and focus on academic areas. . .&nbsp;</p><p><strong>. . .<span class=\"marker\">Participation in an instrumental music program keeps kids busy and committed.</span></strong>&nbsp; A well-run band program requires a time commitment of its participants. . .</p><p><a href=\"S3_BUCKET_/CS6/Op-Ed.html\" onclick=\"window.open(this.href, '', 'resizable=no,status=no,location=no,toolbar=no,menubar=no,fullscreen=no,scrollbars=no,dependent=no,width=800,left=100,height=600,top=50'); return false;\">Previewing: Picture it!</a><br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">Information you have learned from previewing:</span></p><p>1. You know the author is a local person who supports the schools.</p><p>2. You know that the Op-Ed was written recently.</p><p>3. You suspect the author is available to answer questions about this Op-Ed.</p><p>4. You see that he wants his message to be shared through social media.</p><p>5. You have an idea that he will likely&nbsp;present reasons why music education is good for kids.</p>"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"16"},"leftText":"<p>Previewing the Op-Ed has answered some of your guiding questions.&nbsp; You add information to your organizer.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">From the Op-Ed organizer:</span></p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"width:100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><span class=\"marker\">What is the title?</span></td><td><p><span class=\"marker\"><strong>Town Music Shop Blows the Horn on Needed Music Education</strong></span></p></td></tr><tr><td><span class=\"marker\">Who is the author?</span></td><td><span class=\"marker\">Henry Schwinkle</span></td></tr></tbody></table><p><br /><a href=\"S3_BUCKET_/CS6/1/Organizertitleandauthor.pdf\" onclick=\"window.open(this.href, '', 'resizable=yes,status=no,location=no,toolbar=no,menubar=no,fullscreen=no,scrollbars=no,dependent=no,width=800,left=100,height=720,top=50'); </em><br /><br /><strong>Questioning</strong><em> </em>means pausing to ask yourself questions as you read.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":null,"headerText":"Questioning"},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"18"},"leftText":"<p>You can use the active reading strategy of questioning to find the author&#39;s purpose and audience.&nbsp; Read the entire article, asking yourself the questions from the organizer.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<p><span class=\"ju-labels\" style=\"color:#59595B;font-family:tahoma;font-weight:bold;\">&nbsp;From the Op-Ed organizer:</span></p><table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"width:100%;\"><tbody><tr><td>Why is the author writing?</td><td><span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">not filled in&nbsp; </span>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</td></tr><tr><td>Who will read the Op-Ed?</td><td><span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">not filled in&nbsp; </span></td></tr></tbody></table><p><br /><a href=\"S3_BUCKET_/CS6/1/Organizertitleandauthor.pdf\" onclick=\"window.open(this.href, '', 'resizable=yes,status=no,location=no,toolbar=no,menubar=no,fullscreen=no,scrollbars=no,dependent=no,width=800,left=100,height=720,top=50'); return false;\">View the complete Op-Ed organizer&nbsp;<span class=\"screen-reader-only\" style=\"background-color:#FA839F;\">(opens in a new window)</span></a>&nbsp;</p>","headerText":""},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"19"},"leftText":"<p>To find the author&#39;s purpose, you ask yourself, <em>Why did Henry Schwinkle write this?</em><br /><br />You read the first paragraph.&nbsp; This provides background information on the case of Tina Tully and the theft of the musical instruments.&nbsp;<br /><br />You decide that the author&#39;s <strong>purpose</strong>, or reason for writing, is to share information.<br /><br />However, you can&#39;t help wondering, <em>Is this article really about an eight-year-old tuba thief?</em><br /><br />You read more to see if the author has another purpose.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" height=\"359\" style=\"width:100%;\" width=\"363\"><tbody><tr><td><p>. . .(March 3, 2016) The recent unfortunate incident in our town has created speculation about ways to keep our children out of trouble.&nbsp; The case of Tina Tully (also known as Tiny) remains fresh in the minds of all residents.&nbsp; Tina Tully, eight years old, was recently accused of a series of thefts of musical instruments.&nbsp; When local police eventually caught Tina in the act, she confessed, explaining that she was only &ldquo;borrowing&rdquo; one instrument at a time.&nbsp; It happens that she longed to play an instrument, but was not sure which one to choose.&nbsp; So, during a period of several days she sampled a number of musical possibilities, somehow avoiding detection by the staff. She eventually settled on the tuba.&nbsp; When questioned, Tina expressed sadness that her three older brothers had been given access to music lessons while in the local schools.&nbsp; Budget cuts forced the elimination of music programs, so Tina took matters into her own hands.&nbsp; What&rsquo;s a music store owner and police chief to do?&nbsp; That&rsquo;s easy: Tina was forgiven and will perform community service at Tooters weekly for the next three months.&nbsp; Best of all, the store has donated a tuba rental and music lessons to Tina.&nbsp; Happy ending?&nbsp; Not so fast. . .</p></td></tr></tbody></table>","headerText":""},{"settings":{"showAudio":1,"showNext":1,"showHeader":0,"hideRightPanel":0,"delayStep":0,"delayRight":0,"audioPath":"20"},"leftText":"<p>At the end of the next paragraph you read this sentence<em>, We need to bring music back to the schools.</em><br /><br />Aha!&nbsp; You realize that the author&#39;s real purpose is that he wants to convince his readers that music should be taught in schools.<br />&nbsp;</p>","rightText":"<table border=\"1\" cellpadding=\"1\" cellspacing=\"1\" class=\"ju-tableplain ju-tight\" style=\"width:100%;\"><tbody><tr><td><p><strong>. . .The day the music died&mdash;we have lost something.&nbsp; </strong>It is not difficult to establish a connection between this incident and the loss of music programs in our schools.&nbsp; Prior to 2012, students enjoyed many opportunities to participate in music activities, including weekly music class from a certified teacher; optional, free lessons on an instrument of their choice; affordable rentals with an option to buy the instrument; and joining the chorus, a performance orchestra, the marching band, or small, select instrumental groups.&nbsp;&nbsp; Students also could receive counseling and advice offered by music professionals at all schools in our city.&nbsp; Few people are aware that when it was decided to cut a program, the choice was either drama or music.&nbsp;
